newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan firm lifts capital to $11.5 mln on bourse.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan firm lifts capital to $11.5 mln on bourse.

text.p: Morocco's leasing firm Maroc-Leasing increased its capital by 21 percent to 106 million dirhams ($11.5 million) through a floatation on Monday on the Casablanca stock market, a bourse official said.
The closing date for the subscription was set for February 21, 1997, the official said.
One lot of 212,660 shares, or 10 percent of the capital was offered to the public, including foreign investors at a price of 230 dirhams per share, he said.
The second tranche of 106,330 shares would be allocated to mutual funds. Only 1.0 percent of the increased amount will be for company employees, the official added.
The minimum subscription was set at five shares for the public and private investors and 1,000 shares for mutual funds, the firm said.
The firm has now a stock of 1.06 million shares, up from 840,000 shares before floatation, a market analyst said.
Maroc-Leasing's average interest rate on loans have declined over the past three years from 18.8 percent to 15.7 percent in 1996, Casablanca Finance Intermediation (CFI) said.
At the same time, the company's cost of refinancing was declining but at a lower pace, the Casablanca-based CFI said.
Morocco's second largest conglomerate Societe Nationale d'Investissement and Banque Nationale pour le Developpement Economique hold respectively 35 and 65 percent of the firm's stock.
The firm showed a net profit of 8.68 million dirhams in the first nine months of 1996 against 18.1 million dirhams for the whole year of 1995.
Maroc-Leasing expects a net profit of 14.9 million dirhams in 1996, officials said.
It is the second private firm to be floated on the bourse, after credit firm Credor, since the market reform programme was launched by the government in 1993.
The leasing business in Morocco represents an estimated 2.0 billion dirhams turnover annually...It grows at an average of 18.4 percent per year, a stockbroker said.
The firm hold up to 21 percent of the market share, the broker said.
Maroc-Leasing is expected to be listed on the Casablanca stock exchange on February 27, 1997, officials said.
Established in 1929, the Casablanca bourse has 47 listed stocks, including eight banks,
